sub_topic: Prove that every group of order 48 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C48, the alternating group A4 Ã— C4, or one of the 14 non-abelian groups of order 48.
message_1:
Determine which non-abelian group of order 48 is isomorphic to the group G = {e, a, b, c, d, f, g, h, i, j, k, l, m, n, o, p, q, r, s, t, u, v, w, x}, where the operation is defined by the following multiplication table:

|   | e | a | b | c | d | f | g | h | i | j | k | l | m | n | o | p | q | r | s | t | u | v | w | x |
|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| e | e | a | b | c | d | f | g | h | i | j | k | l | m | n | o | p | q | r | s | t | u | v | w | x |
| a | a | e | f | g | b | c | d | j | i | n | m | h | k | l | q | p | s | r | t | u | v | w | x | o |
| b | b | g | e | f | a | d | c | k | l | i | j | n | m | h | r | t | q | s | p | o | x | w | v | u |
| c | c | f | g | e | h | b | a | l | k | j | i | m | n | o | s | r | t | q | p | w | x | u | v | t |
| d | d | h | b | a | e | g | f | m | n | k | l | i | j | q | p | r | s | o | t | v | u | x | w | p |
| f | f | c | d | b | g | e | h | o | q | l | n | j | i | s | t | r | p | w | x | u | v | k | m | a |

| h | h | j | a | d | c | o | p | e | f | q | m | l | k | r | t | n | m | v | u | x | w | s | r | i |
| i | i | k | l | j | b | n | m | f | g | o | p | e | d | t | q | x | w | u | v | s | r | h | j | a |
| j | j | i | k | l | c | m | n | q | o | p | h | d | e | u | v | w | x | s | r | n | m | g | f | b |
| k | k | n | j | i | f | l | k | s | r | e | d | p | o | v | u | t | s | w | x | h | j | c | m | a |
| l | l | m | i | k | h | j | o | r | q | d | e | t | s | x | w | v | u | n | m | f | g | p | o | b |
| m | m | h | n | b | k | i | j | t | s | x | v | q | p | w | x | u | v | l | k | j | e | r | d | a |
| n | n | k | m | f | l | j | i | u | v | s | r | x | w | o | p | h | j | b | a | q | t | d | e | g |
| o | o | q | h | m | n | s | r | j | i | v | u | x | w | p | n | t | s | k | l | d | e | f | g | b |
| p | p | s | k | n | m | r | q | i | j | u | v | w | x | q | l | o | r | j | h | e | d | b | a | f |
| q | q | r | l | o | s | p | n | m | n | f | g | v | u | s | k | l | t | i | j | x | w | h | j | d |
| r | r | t | q | p | o | n | x | n | m | g | f | u | v | j | h | s | q | k | l | b | a | e | d | i |
| s | s | q | p | r | t | x | w | x | v | b | a | s | q | l | n | m | o | h | i | g | f | j | k | e |
| t | t | u | s | q | p | w | x | w | u | a | b | n | m | o | j | k | l | f | g | i | h | p | r | d |

| v | v | w | t | u | r | u | v | j | h | s | q | l | k | i | f | g | b | a | n | t | s | o | m | e |
| w | w | x | u | v | s | f | e | a | b | n | m | r | q | d | h | i | j | p | o | k | l | t | s | g |
| x | x | o | v | w | t | b | a | d | c | m | n | g | f | e | b | a | h | q | p | r | s | n | o | l |

(Hint: Use the Sylow theorems to narrow down the possibilities)
message_2:
Using the Sylow theorems, we can narrow down the possibilities for the group of order 48. The prime factorization of 48 is 2^4 * 3. 

By the Sylow theorems, the number of Sylow 2-subgroups (n_2) must divide 3 and be congruent to 1 mod 2. Therefore, n_2 can be 1 or 3. Similarly, the number of Sylow 3-subgroups (n_3) must divide 16 and be congruent to 1 mod 3. Therefore, n_3 can be 1 or 4.

Now, let's analyze the possibilities:

1. If n_2 = 1 and n_3 = 1, then G has a unique Sylow 2-subgroup and a unique Sylow 3-subgroup, which implies that G is the direct product of these subgroups. In this case, G would be isomorphic to the abelian group Z_16 x Z_3, which contradicts the fact that G is non-abelian.

2. If n_2 = 3 and n_3 = 1, then G has a unique Sylow 3-subgroup, which is normal in G. In this case, G would be a semi-direct product of a Sylow 2-subgroup and the Sylow 3-subgroup. Since the Sylow 3-subgroup is isomorphic to Z_3, the Sylow 2-subgroup must be isomorphic to one of the following groups: Z_16, Z_8 x Z_2, Z_4 x Z_4, or Z_2 x Z_2 x Z_2 x Z_2. However, none of these possibilities lead to a non-abelian group when taking the semi-direct product with Z_3.

3. If n_2 = 1 and n_3 = 4, then G has a unique Sylow 2-subgroup, which is normal in G. In this case, G would be a semi-direct product of the Sylow 2-subgroup and a Sylow 3-subgroup. Since the Sylow 2-subgroup is isomorphic to Z_16, the Sylow 3-subgroup must be isomorphic to Z_3. The semi-direct product of Z_16 and Z_3 is isomorphic to the non-abelian group of order 48 called the generalized quaternion group Q_48.

4. If n_2 = 3 and n_3 = 4, then G has three Sylow 2-subgroups and four Sylow 3-subgroups. In this case, G could be isomorphic to the non-abelian group of order 48 called the dihedral group D_48.

Based on the given multiplication table, we can see that the group G is non-abelian, and it has elements of order 2, 3, 4, and 6. This information is consistent with the structure of the dihedral group D_48. Therefore, we conclude that the group G is isomorphic to the dihedral group D_48.
